title: Combined Model of Biological Project Part and Hardware
author: Team Aachen
abstract: This project involves modeling both the biological processes and the hardware of a Melatonin-sensor system. It aims to understand reaction dynamics, identify key parameters, and predict calibration lines. The model uses Michaelis-Menten and Hill kinetics and integrates these with hardware models for practical applications.

metadata.Model Overview: The model aims to understand the dynamics of reactions in the Melatonin-sensor system and predict its calibration lines. It includes both biological and hardware components.
metadata.Model Assumptions: The models are simplified and do not fully represent the complex realities of enzyme kinetics and hardware interactions.
metadata.Mathematical Description: The biological model uses Michaelis-Menten and Hill kinetics. The hardware model involves an approximation of the LSPR wavelength changes.
metadata.Model Implementation: Implemented using Matlab SimBiology, allowing visual programming and parameter adjustments.
metadata.Parameter Estimation: Parameters were estimated from experimental data and theoretical approximations. Sensitivity analysis was conducted to understand parameter impacts.
metadata.Model Validation and Verification: Validation included comparing simulation results with expected outcomes and conducting sensitivity analyses.
metadata.Simulation Results: Simulations show how melatonin concentrations affect sensor readings, with visualizations provided in Matlab plots.
metadata.Robustness and Sensitivity Analysis: Sensitivity analysis highlighted the impact of melatonin concentration and reaction rates on the system's performance.
metadata.Model Limitations: Simplified models may not capture all real-world complexities. Hardware model approximations may need refinement.
metadata.Conclusions: The combined model helps in understanding the sensor's functionality and predicting performance. It also provides insights for future improvements.
metadata.References: Analytical modeling of localized surface plasmon resonance in heterostructure copper sulfide nanocrystals.
